channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Allies Send More Arms to Ukraine as Russia Accuses NATO of Proxy War
item.description: U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III met in Germany with officials from over 40 countries to plan arms shipments, and Germany pledged heavy weapons for Ukraine in a policy reversal.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktor Hubenko, a resident of the Novo Yakovlevka village in the Zaporizhzhia region, moves a sign reading “mine” to mark his cellar, struck by a Russian projectile on Tuesday.

item.title: Under Fire, a Ukrainian Town Braces for a Russian Onslaught
item.description: In Orikhiv, near the front lines, most residents have fled and those who remain endure constant shelling and the fear of what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tamara Mikheenko, 70, cries while hiding in a basement shelter as she talks about the incessant shelling of the frontline town of Orikhiv, in Eastern Ukraine.

item.title: China’s Covid Strategy: Test Most Residents in Beijing Amid Lockdown Fears
item.description: China’s capital reported 22 cases as it kicked off an ambitious mandatory testing campaign across the city and reassured residents that food and other supplies were plentiful.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A testing site in the Haidian district of Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Amid Virus Chaos, Shanghai Residents Band Together
item.description: As the authorities in China’s biggest city fight to stamp out an Omicron outbreak, neighbors are turning to one another for support.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Amy Chang Chien and Isabelle Qian
item.media:description: Green fences sealing entrances to shops and residences on Sunday in Shanghai, where many neighborhoods have been locked down to fight an outbreak of Covid-19.

item.title: Convincing Victory Disguises Challenges for France’s Macron
item.description: France’s runoff election was marked by a record level of abstention, and many cast a ballot only to keep the far right from power — a testament to a growing disillusionment.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron at a rally in Paris on Sunday night after the runoff vote. He became the first French leader to be re-elected to a second term in 20 years.

item.title: North Korea Holds Military Parade With Nuclear Threat
item.description: In a speech, Kim Jong-un, the country’s leader, vowed to expand his nuclear arsenal ​“at the fastest possible speed​.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed what it says was a newly built intercontinental ballistic missile, the Hwasong-17, during a military parade in Pyongyang, North Korea.

item.title: Baking Challah in Dubai: A Jewish Community Heads Out Into the Open
item.description: The increasing openness of Jewish life in the Persian Gulf emirate of Dubai is another sign of an emerging new reality in the Middle East, where Israel’s isolation by the Arab world is ebbing.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar and The New York Times
item.media:description: Women making challah bread in February in Dubai.

item.title: Brownface in Hong Kong TV Show Draws Outrage and Shrugs
item.description: The TV show “Barrack O’Karma 1968” fueled debate online. To many Filipinos, it was about racism and classism. Other viewers jumped to the actress’s defense.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: TVB headquarters and studios in Tseung Kwan O, the New Territories, Hong Kong, in 2018. The 55-year-old broadcaster is known for variety shows and serial dramas.

item.title: Kenneth Roth, ‘Godfather’ of Human Rights Work, to Step Down
item.description: Mr. Roth joined Human Rights Watch when it was a fledgling organization. It has expanded into one of the most influential human rights advocacy groups.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, this week in New York. He has been an unrelenting irritant to authoritarian governments.

item.title: Macron’s Win Is Also a Blow to Orban’s Nationalist Crusade in Europe
item.description: The Hungarian leader had cast his own victory as the start of a nationalist wave in Europe — one that Marine Le Pen would have joined. Instead, Mr. Macron’s victory in France is a win for the European Union’s approach.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris on Sunday night. He overcame a challenge from Marine Le Pen, a far-right candidate, for a second term.

item.title: Seeking Arms for Ukraine, Pentagon Buyers Scour Eastern European Factories
item.description: Soviet-designed ammunition is part of the ‘life blood’ for Ukrainian troops fighting Russia, and the United States is keeping it flowing.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A delivery of equipment and defensive munitions provided by the United States, including nearly 300 Javelin anti-tank missiles, arriving at Kyiv Boryspil Airport from Dover Air Force Base in January.

item.title: How Zelensky Tamed Ukraine’s Fractious Politics and Stood Up to Putin
item.description: Ukrainian politics were known for sharp-elbowed infighting. But as he defends his country against the Russian invasion, President Volodymyr Zelensky has his government presenting a unified front.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Tries to Reinvent Himself After Re-election
item.description: France seems in search of a kinder, gentler, greener President Macron. He says he will listen.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris on Sunday. The years ahead, he said in his victory speech, “will not be tranquil, but they will be historic, and we will write them together for the generations to come.”

item.title: Turkish Activist Osman Kavala Sentenced to Life Over Protests
item.description: Osman Kavala, a well-known activist, was found guilty of charges related to popular protests in 2013.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur and Elif Ince
item.media:description: The Caglayan Justice Palace courthouse in Istanbul last month. The case of Osman Kavala and other defendants is part of a widespread crackdown after a coup attempt in 2016.

item.title: As Diplomacy Hopes Dim, U.S. Marshals Allies to Furnish Long-Term Military Aid to Ukraine
item.description: Germany said it would send Ukraine dozens of armored antiaircraft vehicles, a major shift for a country that has been reluctant to escalate the conflict with Russia.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay, Christopher F. Schuetze and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, center, at the Ukraine Security Consultative Group meeting in Ramstein, Germany, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.K. Tabloid Accuses Lawmaker of ‘Basic Instinct’ Move
item.description: Citing an unnamed Conservative lawmaker, the paper claimed that Angela Rayner, a Labour leader, tried to distract Boris Johnson with her body. Fury has ensued.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Ms. Rayner during a Labour Party conference last year.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Beijing’s Mass Testing Plan
item.description: Plus more aggressive support for Ukraine and Hong Kong’s brownface controversy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Beijing officials said samples had been gathered from nearly four million people on Monday alone.

item.title: Explosions in Separatist Region of Moldova Raise Fears of Wider War
item.description: The blasts in Transnistria, a region bordering Ukraine that is run by Russia-backed separatists, have fueled talk of Moldova being dragged into the war.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The border in Moldova of the breakaway region of Transnistria, which was hit with a series of explosions on Monday and Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Cuts Off a Major Supply of Natural Gas to Poland
item.description: Poland gets more than 45 percent of its natural gas from Russia, most of it through a single pipeline that will no longer make deliveries to the country.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Pipelines near a gas processing facility operated by Gazprom on the Yamal Peninsula in Russia's Arctic region.

item.title: What Are the New Rules on Light Bulbs?: LED vs. Incandescent
item.description: The administration set efficiency standards that will phase out sales of incandescent bulbs in favor of LEDs, reducing Americans’ electrical bills over time.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: The Department of Energy said that, once the rules are in place next year, Americans will save $3 billion on utility bills.

item.title: U.S.-Led Group Nations Will Meet Monthly to Plan Ukraine Aid
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III announced the formation of the Ukraine Contact Group, with more than 40 member nations, to coordinate military and humanitarian assistance.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: U.S. Secretary of Defense, Lloyd Austin, addresses the media after meeting with defense and military chiefs of more than 40 countries at Ramstein Air Base in Germany, Tuesday.

item.title: Here’s what an unvaccinated police sergeant in New Jersey, who nearly died of Covid, wants you to know.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Frank Talarico was hospitalized for 49 days with the coronavirus. “If it’s an eye opener for somebody — so be it,” he said.

item.title: Tony Blair on Russia’s War in Ukraine: A Virtual Event
item.description: The former British prime minister will speak with Peter Baker of The New York Times on May 2.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: As Mask Mandates End, Canada’s Atlantic Provinces See Rise in Covid Cases
item.description: Once relatively shielded from the virus transmission waves that flooded the rest of Canada, coronavirus infections are rising in the easternmost provinces.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bonavista, Newfoundland, in October. Newfoundland and Labrador province recorded its highest number of Covid-19 deaths this April and has also reduced its daily data reporting.

item.title: A Billionaires’ World
item.description: The world’s richest person didn’t like Twitter. So he’s buying it.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Elon Musk

item.title: Do Vaccines Protect Against Long Covid?
item.description: Maybe, according to a growing number of studies, but there’s not yet a definitive answer.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Receiving a boster shot in Los Angeles this month.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: U.S. military aims in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian boy climbing on a charred tank in the ruins of Hostomel, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Biden Picks Bridget Brink to Be Ambassador to Ukraine
item.description: The U.S. Embassy, which closed just before Russia’s invasion, could reopen “over a couple of weeks,” Secretary of State Antony Blinken said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Aziz Karimov/Pacific Press/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bridget Brink, President Biden’s selection, would be the first Senate-confirmed ambassador to hold the Ukraine post since mid-2019.

item.title: How the U.S. Is Shifting Its Approach on Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: The United States is edging toward a dynamic that pits Washington more directly against Moscow, and one that U.S. officials see as likely to play out for years.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, left, and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III in Poland on Monday, after a stealth visit to Ukraine.

item.title: Emboldened by Ukraine’s Grit, U.S. Wants to See Russia Weakened
item.description: Hours after the American secretaries of defense and state met with Ukraine’s president in Kyiv, Russia hit at least five Ukrainian railway stations in rocket attacks.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, John Ismay and Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexander Buriak on a charred Ukrainian tank on Monday in Hostomel, Ukraine. The boy’s family had been evacuated on March 10, after his father, Vladislav, was shot in the arm by a Russian sniper. On April 13 the family returned.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Elon Musk Buys Twitter
item.description: Plus a lockdown looms over Beijing and the U.S. flexes in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Elon Musk has purchased Twitter for close to $44 billion.

item.title: Explosions Hit Transnistria, a Region of Moldova in Ukraine
item.description: No injuries were reported in the area that has a large ethnic Russian population.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: Fires Rip Through Russian Oil Facility in Bryansk, Close to Ukrainian Border
item.description: Russian state television reported two separate explosions, but officials acknowledged only one.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A screengrab from a video released by state-run Russian news agency Ria Novosti claimed to show a large fire that broke out early on Monday at an oil storage facility in the city of Bryansk.

item.title: To tackle inequality, Macron plans a ‘purchasing power package.’
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stiring-Wendel, in northeastern France, in early April. Emmanuel Macron has proposed increasing pensions and raising social subsidies for households strained by inflation.

item.title: France’s Larger Meaning
item.description: Emmanuel Macron won, but radical politics isn’t going away.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron shakes at an election night rally in Paris.

item.title: Putin Congratulates Macron on French Election Victory
item.description: Mr. Macron’s opponent, Marine Le Pen, was seen in Russia as a potential game-changing option, amid the threat of new sanctions over the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, met with President Emmanuel Macron of France in Moscow in February, weeks before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Four People Fatally Stabbed in London
item.description: A suspect was in custody Monday morning, and the police say they believe the attacker and the victims knew each other.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Police investigating the stabbing deaths of four people in London on Monday morning.

item.title: A Long Walk Through Japan’s Kii Peninsula
item.description: As is true throughout rural Japan, many of the once-vibrant villages on Honshu’s Kii Peninsula are aging into nothingness.
item.dc:creator: Craig Mod

item.title: China’s Covid Lockdowns Stir Memories of a Planned Economy
item.description: China is meddling with free enterprise as it hadn’t in decades. The results are familiar to those old enough to remember: scarcity, and the rise of black markets.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: How Blinken and Austin Entered Ukraine Despite Security Risks
item.description: After President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spilled the secret that the secretaries of state and defense would visit, the two cabinet members decided to press onward regardless.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, left, and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III in Poland on Monday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Top U.S. officials in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken during a meeting with Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine on Friday in Washington.

item.title: Covid Outbreak in Beijing Prompts Order for Nearly Citywide Testing
item.description: Supermarkets stocked up as panic buying began. Municipal authorities ordered that almost all residents be tested three times this week to contain a rising number of cases.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Shelves at a supermarket began emptying out as shoppers rushed to stock up on Sunday following a coronavirus outbreak in the Chaoyang District of Beijing.

item.title: Biden Nominates Bridget Brink as U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine
item.description: President Biden nominated Bridget Brink, the current U.S. ambassador to Slovakia, as ambassador to Ukraine. The position has been empty for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Aziz Karimov/Pacific Press--LightRocket, via Getty Image
item.media:description: Bridget Brink during a visit to Azerbaijan in 2018.

item.title: Arab Militia Kills Scores in Sweeping Attack in Sudan’s Darfur
item.description: The assault by hundreds of Janjaweed fighters, the latest in a series of clashes, was another sign of Sudan's deepening security and political crisis.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Faiz Abubakar Muhamed for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shelters of displaced people in El Geneina, in Sudan’s Darfur region, in March.

item.title: U.S. Officials Make Top-Secret Visit to Ukraine
item.description: The American government refused to comment on reports that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had traveled to Ukraine to meet with its leaders.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Natalie Kitroeff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers attending an Orthodox Easter service at a front-line base near Zaporizhzhia on Sunday.

item.title: Blinken and Austin Arrive in Kyiv to Show Support for Ukraine
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III met Sunday with President Volodymyr Zelensky, the first senior U.S. officials known to have visited Ukraine since the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken during a meeting with Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine on Friday in Washington.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Defeats Marine Le Pen for Second Term as French President
item.description: The result was a relief to allies in Europe and Washington wary of a far-right challenger who was hostile to the European Union and NATO.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron celebrated his victory on Sunday evening in Paris.

item.title: Slovenia Election: Europe’s Far-Right Populists Suffer Another Setback
item.description: The country’s prime minister, Janez Jansa, a Trump admirer, appears to have lost to centrist rivals.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Robert Golob, leader of the Freedom Movement party, speaking to supporters in Ljubljana, Slovenia, on Sunday. Mr. Golob could not appear in person due to a positive Covid test.

item.title: America’s Road to the Ukraine War
item.description: For years, the United States sent mixed signals about its interests in the country. Then Vladimir V. Putin made his move.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration in support of Ukraine near the White House in April.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Macron Wins Re-election
item.description: Plus an announced visit by top U.S. officials to Kyiv, while New Zealand and Japan announce closer diplomatic ties.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: French President and La Republique en Marche (LREM) party candidate for re-election Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte Macron celebrate after his victory in France’s presidential election.

item.title: In a Ukrainian School, 12 People Await the War’s End, or Their Own
item.description: In the basement of a battered school in Kharkiv, a dozen residents have taken shelter. In a neighborhood not far away, life has returned to some sense of normalcy. But they choose to stay.
item.media:description: Natalia Skvortova sheltering in the basement of Kharkiv Municipal Gymnasium No. 172. The school secretary, she wants to protect against looting and prevent records from being destroyed.

item.title: A Family of Six Walks for Days to Escape Mariupol
item.description: At times, Russian soldiers were almost friendly, advising them how to avoid shelling and showing them pictures of their own children.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yevhen Tishchenko and his wife, Tetiana Komisarova, with their children on Easter Sunday at a shelter in Lviv, Ukraine.

item.title: Modi Stresses Growth, Sidestepping Politics, in Visit to Restive Territory
item.description: The Indian prime minister aims to ease decades of turmoil in Jammu and Kashmir through projects like a solar plant.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, sitting center and shown on a big screen, was flanked by regional officials on Sunday in a visit to Palli, a village in Jammu, Kashmir.

item.title: Ukrainians in Mariupol’s Steel Plant Are Holding On, a Commander Tells the Times
item.description: Capt. Svyatoslav Palamar says he and others would give up the factory if they could leave safely.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: The Azovstal iron and steel plant, in the background, in the southern port city of Mariupol, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Demolishing City of the Dead Will Displace a Lively Quarter of Cairo
item.description: Cairo’s oldest cemetery is being razed, and thousands of families living amid the grand mausoleums face eviction. “You’re not at ease when you’re living. You’re not at ease even when you’re dead.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Cairo’s oldest cemetery, both the living and the dead, are facing eviction. The carved antique wooden doors and marble have aleady been removed from many mausoleums.

item.title: With Us or With Them? In a New Cold War, How About Neither.
item.description: Old geopolitical foes are facing off after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but much of the world is refusing to take sides.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Abdi Latif Dahir and Oscar Lopez
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rubble in a residential area after an attack in the town of Borodianka, Ukraine, in April.

item.title: How hated is Macron? The answer could decide the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke to factory workers this month in Le Havre.
